text:
LUCIANA BAIGUN:
Around 80% of car

trips are for less
than a few miles.

And at Bird, we think
that micromobility

could revolutionize
the world, literally

change the landscape of
all the cities around us.
And I've seen it firsthand.

Here in LA, two years
ago, Bird didn't exist.

And now you see scooters and
electric bikes everywhere.

I always felt that at
some point in my life

I wanted to do something
based on my values.

And I wasn't quite
getting there.
Well, my parents are ecologists.

My grandfather defended
political prisoners.

He would say to me
[NON-ENGLISH SPEECH] Find ways

to put your abilities or skills
at the service of others,

and that's where your
vocation will be.

If you're in business,
it can be from being

a really good manager
to working at a mission
within the company.

What excites me about managing
people and leading teams

is that ability to
make a difference.
You learn from them.
They learn from you.

And every day you
work together when

you're moving one step closer
to achieving a common goal.

And at Bird, reducing
carbon emissions

isn't a nice side effect; it's
the main goal of the company.

I'm fighting the
good fight along

with my parents and
my grandparents.

Over the next 10 years, I hope
to see big, dramatic change,

that I will wake up one day
and look outside my window

and see more people on bikes
or scooters instead of cars

and know that I played
even a small role in making
that difference.
